documenttitle.text: Red Hat Security Advisory: up2date improperly checks the GPG package signatures.

note.text:
Updated up2date packages for Red Hat Linux 8.0 and 9 fix RPM GPG signature
verification.
note.title: Topic

note.text:
The Red Hat Update Agent, up2date, automatically queries the Red Hat
Network servers and determines which packages need to be updated on
a machine.

Versions 3.0.7 and 3.1.23 of up2date (the versions found in Red Hat Linux
8.0 and 9) check RPM GPG signatures incorrectly.

This bug allows packages with no GPG signature to be installed by
up2date if they are provided by the Red Hat Network servers. The intended
behaviour is that only packages signed with the Red Hat package signing key
are installed. 

Because connections to the Red Hat Network servers are authenticated and
verified using of SSL, it is nearly impossible to intercept the connection
to Red Hat Network servers and supply unsigned packages. For this reason,
to take advantage of this exploit an attacker must compromise the Red Hat
Network servers at Red Hat and make unsigned packages appear on Red Hat
Network.

These facts make the risk of exploiting this bug very low. However,
it is advised that all users of up2date install the packages contained
within this erratum, which correct this issue by rejecting and refusing to
install any packages with no GPG signature -- treating such packages in the
same way as those with bad GPG signatures.

Note: All other variations of package signature checking work correctly. 

Red Hat would like to thank Barry Nathan for finding and reporting this error.

description.text:
Before applying this update, make sure all previously released errata
relevant to your system have been applied.

To update all RPMs for your particular architecture, run:

rpm -Fvh [filenames]

where [filenames] is a list of the RPMs you wish to upgrade.  Only those
RPMs which are currently installed will be updated.  Those RPMs which are
not installed but included in the list will not be updated.  Note that you
can also use wildcards (*.rpm) if your current directory *only* contains the
desired RPMs.

Please note that this update is also available via Red Hat Network.  Many
people find this an easier way to apply updates.  To use Red Hat Network,
launch the Red Hat Update Agent with the following command:

up2date

This will start an interactive process that will result in the appropriate
RPMs being upgraded on your system.
